title: Butter vs. Plant Oils: Which One Helps You Live Longer?
description: A Harvard study found that replacing 10g of butter per day with plant oils like olive or canola significantly reduces mortality risk. This is due to unsaturated fats and antioxidants in plant oils that benefit cholesterol and reduce inflammation.
source: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

title: What Does a Healthy Diet Really Look Like?
description: According to Mayo Clinic, a healthy diet includes a balance of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, whole grains, low-fat dairy, and healthy fats. Customization based on health needs and sustainability are key to long-term success.

title: 25 Simple Ways to Eat Healthier Without a Drastic Diet
description: Healthline offers easy tips like using smaller plates, eating veggies first, and swapping sugary drinks for water. Gradual changes like choosing whole grains and adding more protein make a big impact over time.

title: Daily Habits That Make Healthy Eating Easy
description: WebMD shares habits such as spiralizing veggies, meal prepping, and tracking food intake. The focus is on sustainable changes like adding healthy options instead of cutting everything out at once.

title: Midlife Diet Predicts How Well You’ll Age
description: BBC reports that diets rich in plant-based foods during your 40s increase your odds of aging healthily by up to 84%. Poor diets high in processed foods are linked to worse aging outcomes.

title: Chia Seeds – Tiny Powerhouses of Hydration!
description: Chia seeds can absorb up to 12 times their weight in water, helping your body stay hydrated longer.

title: Bananas: The Surprisingly Radioactive Fruit
description: Yes, bananas are mildly radioactive! They contain the isotope potassium-40, which emits a tiny amount of radiation.

title: Red Bell Pepper Packs More Vitamin C Than Oranges!
description: A medium red bell pepper provides about 169% of the daily vitamin C you need far more than an orange. That means one pepper can give your immune system a big boost!

title: Sun-Kissed Mushrooms = Vitamin D Boost
description: Mushrooms are unique: when exposed to sunlight or UV light, they naturally produce vitamin D2. So letting mushrooms “sunbathe” turns them into a vegan-friendly source of vitamin D for bone health and immunity.

title: Spice Up Your Metabolism!
description: Eating spicy foods (thanks to capsaicin in peppers) can slightly boost your metabolism. Research suggests capsaicin makes your body burn a bit more energy and even helps reduce appetite - a tasty way to accelerate calorie burn!

title: Dark Chocolate: The (Tasty) Brain Booster
description: Dark chocolate is rich in flavanols that can improve short-term brain function. In one study, people who ate high-flavanol dark chocolate scored better on memory and reaction-time tests a few hours later. It’s a delicious way to give your brain a little lift!

title: Leafy Greens for a Sharper Mind
description: Just one serving of leafy greens per day may slow cognitive aging. A study found people who ate greens like spinach or kale daily had slower memory decline over time. Adding salad to your meals isn’t just healthy – it could help keep your mind sharp!

title: Blueberries: Tiny Berries, Big Brain Benefit
description: Blueberries are packed with antioxidants that may delay brain aging and improve memory. These compounds accumulate in the brain and help cells communicate – a few handfuls of berries could be the ultimate brain snack!

title: Salmon & Fish: Fuel for Your Brain
description: Omega-3 fatty acids in fish keep your brain sharp and energetic. Eating fish is linked to better mood, improved sleep, and may even help ward off Alzheimer’s, making it a brain-health champion. Aim for two servings of fish per week!

title: Fiber: Tiny Nutrient, Big Heart Benefits
description: Boosting your fiber intake can dramatically improve heart health. Harvard research found high-fiber diets could slash heart attack risk by 30%, and even adding just 5g more fiber a day lowered inflammation markers linked to heart disease. Whole grains and veggies are your heart’s best friends!

title: Strawberry? Not-so-berry
description: Despite their name, strawberries aren't really berries.

title: Strawberries have their seeds on the outside
description: Those little dots on the outside of strawberries are achenes that contain a seed.

title: Uncooked potatoes may be dangerous!
description: Raw potatoes conatin chaconine, which may have negative effects on your digestive system

title: Bananas with seeds
description: Some of wild-type bananas contain large, hard seeds

title: The smell of durian
description: Due to the smell durian, some public transport comapnies have decided to ban the fruit.
